    Download Hi-Res ImageDownload to MS-PowerPointCite This:J. Med. Chem. 2018, 61, 16, 7289-7313
    ADVERTISEMENT
    RETURN TO ISSUEPREVArticleNEXT

    Design, Synthesis, and SAR of C-3 Benzoic Acid, C-17 Triterpenoid Derivatives. Identification of the HIV-1 Maturation Inhibitor 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-((2-(1,1-Dioxidothiomorpholino)ethyl)amino)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoic Acid (GSK3532795, BMS-955176)

    • Alicia Regueiro-Ren*

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    GSK3532795, formerly known as BMS-955176 (1), is a potent, orally active, second-generation HIV-1 maturation inhibitor (MI) that advanced through phase IIb clinical trials. The careful design, selection, and evaluation of substituents appended to the C-3 and C-17 positions of the natural product betulinic acid (3) was critical in attaining a molecule with the desired virological and pharmacokinetic profile. Herein, we highlight the key insights made in the discovery program and detail the evolution of the structure–activity relationships (SARs) that led to the design of the specific C-17 amine moiety in 1. These modifications ultimately enabled the discovery of 1 as a second-generation MI that combines broad coverage of polymorphic viruses (EC50 <15 nM toward a panel of common polymorphisms representative of 96.5% HIV-1 subtype B virus) with a favorable pharmacokinetic profile in preclinical species.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Current therapies to treat human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1) infection have transformed acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) into a chronic disease for the majority of patients. Combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) consists of multiple antiviral agents with complementary mechanisms of action (MOAs) and resistance profiles that is optimally administered as part of a convenient, fixed-dose regimen that simplifies patient compliance.(1) However, the search for medicines with novel MOAs that are capable of overcoming the resistance that could eventually emerge in response to therapy, as well as improved safety profiles that are compatible with the long-term administration of these agents, is still of vital importance.(2)
    Inhibition of the maturation step of the virus life circle for the treatment of HIV-1 infection/AIDS has been the focus of significant attention over the last 30 years.(2,3) Maturation of the HIV-1 virion is mediated by the viral protease, which sequentially cleaves the Gag polyprotein in five different places to release the structural proteins, matrix (MA), capsid (CA), nucleocapsid (NC), and p6, as well as two spacer peptides, SP1 and SP2.(4,5) HIV-1 protease inhibitors (PIs), which act at the latter stage of the virus life cycle, impede maturation of the virus by binding to the virally encoded protease, thereby preventing all of the proteolytic cleavages from occurring. In contrast, maturation inhibitors (MIs) have been shown to bind to the virally encoded Gag polyprotein proximal to the CA-SP1 junction and specifically preclude cleavage at this site, which is the final and rate-limiting step in the virion maturation process. The advent of PIs has provided an efficacious therapy to treat AIDS, and an MI would provide an alternative approach to effect a similar therapeutic intervention while offering a complementary resistance profile. While there are 10 Federal Drug Administration (FDA)-approved HIV-1 PIs, some of which are used as an integral part of cART (although most PIs need to be coadministered with a pharmacokinetic enhancer such as ritonavir or cobicistat), only a few MIs have been advanced into clinical trials.(6,7) GSK3532795, formerly known as BMS-955176 (1, Figure 1), is a second-generation HIV-1 MI with broad polymorphic virus coverage.(8,9) The discovery program that led to the development of 1 was grounded on overcoming the limitations observed with bevirimat (2, Figure 1), the first compound with this MOA that was advanced into clinical trials and which established proof-of-concept for this therapeutic intervention strategy.(9,10) Administration of 2 at doses of 150 and 250 mg once a day (quaque die, QD) in a 10 day phase I/II monotherapy trial resulted in mean viral load reductions (VLRs) of 0.72 log10 copies/mL.(10) However, in a phase IIa monotherapy clinical trial conducted in highly ART-experienced patients, 55% of the individuals in the study treated with 2 did not experience a significant VLR (defined as >0.5 log10 copies/mL). It was subsequently determined that all of the nonresponders were infected with viruses that expressed naturally occurring polymorphic variations proximal to the CA/SP1 cleavage site at amino acid residues Q369-V370-T371 of the Gag polyprotein.(11−13) Mutations at position V362, which is immediately adjacent to the L363-A364 cleavage site, were subsequently identified as being involved in reducing the response to 2.(13) In addition, 2 displayed high human serum (HS) binding (>99%), reducing the free fraction of the drug in plasma and contributing to the need for an elevated dose, as well as poor aqueous solubility (<1 μg/mL), which limited options for formulation.(14,15) The lack of coverage of naturally occurring polymorphic viruses and the formulation challenges prevented further development of 2 but highlighted the characteristics needed for an improved MI clinical candidate.(16) A second-generation MI should demonstrate efficacy against these polymorphic viruses, be suitable for administration at a low dose, and be compatible with other agents in order to facilitate combinations as a part of a cART regimen. This manuscript describes the drug design and optimization efforts that led to the discovery and preclinical characterization of 1 as a second-generation MI with broad polymorphic virus coverage and the potential for QD dosing. Compound 1 is a derivative of 3 (Figure 1) that incorporates a 4-substituted benzoic acid at C-3 of the triterpene core and a diamine-containing side chain installed at the C-17 position.(9) GSK3532795 was examined in a phase IIb clinical trial where it proved to be efficacious, although development was terminated recently due to unacceptable rates of adverse gastrointestinal events and treatment-emergent NRTI resistance (GSK3532795 was coadministered with an NRTI).

    Results

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Biological and Pharmacokinetic Profiling of Compounds

    To facilitate the identification of a second-generation MI, a primary screening tier comprised of wild-type (WT) HIV-1 and two key polymorphic viruses was implemented along with monitoring of the effect of added HS on the inhibition of WT HIV-1 by compounds with promising profiles. The two polymorphic viruses that were selected for the primary screen were V370A, for which there is a high prevalence of changes (∼17% V370A/M) at this position in HIV-1 subtype-B viruses and which demonstrated a reduced clinical response to the first-generation MI 2 and ΔV370. While ΔV370 is present in only ∼1% of B-subtype viruses, it exhibits a high level of resistance (>1000-fold) to 2, therefore representing a challenging and stringent case with which to drive the SARs. Additionally, the ΔV370 polymorph is common (>70%) in nonsubtype-B HIV-1 viruses. Newly synthesized compounds were screened for antiviral activity toward WT HIV-1, V370A, and ΔV370 polymorphic viruses in a virus replication assay in which the Nef gene was replaced with a luciferase reporter and which replicated in MT-2 cells infected for 4–5 days.(8) The concentration at which test compounds were half-maximally cytotoxic toward the host cell (CC50) was also determined. Selected compounds were rescreened in the WT HIV-1 cell culture assay in the presence of HS, with the results compiled in Table 1. Except where noted, all compounds exhibited high metabolic stability in vitro with t1/2 values of >120 min when incubated in rat and human liver microsomes (RLM and HLM) in the presence of NADPH, which predicted for low clearance in vivo. It was not possible to assess the in vitro membrane permeability of any of the test compounds due to their limited solubility under the assay conditions. Representative compounds were evaluated for their in vivo pharmacokinetic (PK) profile either in an abbreviated, 6 h snapshot rat PK screen or in a full, 24 h rat PK study. The compounds were dosed at 5 mg/kg PO, and the results are included in Table 1.
    Table 1. In Vitro Antiviral Potency, Cytotoxicity, and in Vivo Rat Pharmacokinetic Profiling Data for MIs
    a

    The data provided are the means of at least triplicate values with mean CVs (confidence values) of 83 ± 50% for all of the experiments, and all CV values were <200%. Where experiments were performed four or more times, the standard deviations are included.

    b

    Compounds were evaluated for serum effects in 10% FBS + 40% human serum except for 1 (10% FBS + 40% human serum +27 mg/mL human serum albumin).

    c

    Dose 5 mg/kg PO; for vehicle information see Experimental Section.

    d

    n = 2.

    e

    n = 3.

    Compound Synthesis

    Amides 6 and 7 were prepared accordingly to previously described procedures.(17,18)Scheme 1 describes the synthesis of C-17 amine derivatives of C-3 benzoic acid-based betulinic acid derived MIs 23–28.(19)
    The oxidation of betulin (8) to betulonic acid (9) was accomplished in a synthetically and economically efficient manner. Exposure of 8 to TPAP/NMO concomitantly oxidized the two alcohol moieties and was followed by Pinnick oxidation of the newly formed C-28 aldehyde to afford 9 in an overall yield of 70–80%, circumventing the previously reported method which relied upon the more expensive 3 as starting material.(9,17−22) Treatment of 9 with benzyl bromide in the presence of base protectively esterified the carboxylic acid moiety and was followed by conversion of the C-3 ketone into the corresponding enol triflate 10. Suzuki–Miyaura coupling of 10 with (4-methoxycarbonyl)phenylboronic acid rendered 11. Deprotection of 11 was accomplished by exposing to t-butyldimethylsilane in the presence of Pd(OAc)2, followed by the addition of TBAF, which afforded carboxylic acid 12 via an intermediate silyl ester, a procedure that prevented the hydrogenation of the olefins observed when using other reduction methods.(23) Curtius rearrangement of 12 afforded isocyanate 13, which was treated with 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)- or 4-(2-aminoethyl)-thiomorpholine 1,1-dioxide to provide carbamate 23 or urea 24, respectively, after hydrolysis of the methyl benzoate.(24,25) Acidic hydrolysis of isocyanate 13 provided the C-17 primary amine 14 that was converted into amides 25–28 by coupling with the corresponding carboxylic acid in the presence of HATU, followed by deprotection of the methyl benzoate under basic conditions.(25)
    The synthesis of the C-17 alkylamine derivatives prepared by the direct alkylation of 14 is depicted in Scheme 2.(19,25) Alkylation of 14 with alkyl halides in the presence of K3PO4 and KI followed by deprotection of the benzoic acid afforded C-17 amines 1, 30, 34–36, 38, and 45 as well as the 3′-fluoro analogue 48, a compound that required the use of (2-fluoro-4-(methoxycarbonyl)phenyl)boronic acid in the Suzuki–Miyaura reaction. Thiopyran derivative 33 was prepared from 14 via sulfide 15, followed by oxidation with oxone and ester deprotection. Alkylation of 14 with N-(4-(2-chloroethyl)-1-oxido-6-thiomorpholin-1-ylidene)-4-methylbenzenesulfonamide afforded 16, which upon treatment with Hg amalgam in the presence of base generated sulfoximine 47.(26,27)
    Reductive amination of 14 with the corresponding aldehydes afforded intermediates 17–19 as shown in Scheme 3.(19) Removal of the protecting groups from 17 provided 32. Acid hydrolysis of the Boc-protected amine 18 followed by Michael addition to vinylsulfonylethene and final deprotection rendered 29. Alternatively, 36 was obtained via reductive amination of the primary amine generated from 19 using tert-butyl-3-oxopyrrolidine-1-carboxylate and 2-methylpyridine borane (Pic-BH3) followed by standard BOC deprotection, sulfonylation, and final ester deprotection.(28)
    Piperidine derivatives 31 and 37 and sulfonamide 39 were prepared from 14 in four steps as shown in Scheme 4.(19) Alkylation of 14 with bromoethanol followed by treatment of the alcohol with thionyl chloride rendered alkyl chloride 20. Displacement of the terminal chloride with an amine followed by benzoate ester deprotection afforded 31, 37, and 39. Conversely, the addition of t-butylpiperazine-1-carboxylate to 20 followed by Boc-deprotection using HCl gave the terminal piperazine 21. Addition of isopropylsulfonyl choride to 21 followed by deprotection of the ester under standard conditions provided piperazine sulfonamide 40.
    Alkylation of 14 with 1-bromo-2-chloroethane afforded aziridine 22 in 98% yield. Nucleophilic ring opening of the aziridine by the addition of mono-Boc protected diamines followed by unmasking of the terminal amine moiety, subsequent sulfonylation, and deprotection of the benzoic acid under standard conditions afforded bicyclic sulfonamides 41–43 and 46(25) (Scheme 5).

    Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    We have previously described the initial key structural modifications that led to the discovery of 1.(9,17,18,20) The introduction of a 4-substituted benzoic acid moiety at the C-3 position of the core of 3 provided a carbon-linked motif that preserved unique aspects of the topology and topography and the relationship of the carboxylic acid moiety of 2 with the triterpenoid core.(17) The incorporation of basic amines at the C-28 position via an amide linker (C-28 amides) or an amine linker (C-28 amines) rendered compounds with good antiviral potency toward not only the WT virus but also toward the V370A and ΔV370 polymorphic viruses that experienced lower shifts in the presence of HS when compared with 2 (5-fold for 4). However, with respect to pharmacokinetic properties, both C-28 amide and C-28 amine derivatives showed lower AUC values following oral dosing to rats when compared with 2. Modulation of the overall basicity of the molecule by reducing the pKa of the terminal amine by incorporation into a thiomorpholine-1,1-dioxide (TMD) ring, pKa = 5.4,(29) as in 4, resulted in a modest improvement in the AUC when compared with other C-28 analogues bearing amine-containing side chains while maintaining excellent potency toward the polymorphic viruses.(20) We have shown that installing a carboxylic acid moiety in the C-28 side chain can help to improve oral exposure, although the polymorphic coverage was negatively affected, as exemplified by the profile of 5.(18) Recognizing the potential of the sulfone moiety to act as a surrogate of the two oxygen atoms of a carboxylic acid but without the burden of charge and encouraged by the results obtained with 4, we prepared amides 6 and 7 with the purpose of improving polymorphic coverage while preserving the advantageous PK profile associated with a carboxylic acid derivative. However, while both 6 and 7 displayed superior potency toward WT, V370A, and ΔV370 viruses when compared to 5, the plasma AUC following oral dosing of 7 to rats was significantly lower than observed with 5 and even 4. The SARs that emerged from the C-28 derivatives 4–7 clearly established the need for a side chain bearing both an amine moiety and a polar functionality in order to combine targeted polymorphic coverage with good PK properties. However, the modifications implemented in the context of the C-28 amine/amide series were not sufficient to support the further advancement of any of these compounds.(20) At this point, it was postulated that positioning both the C-28 and TMD amine moieties closer to the triterpenoid core may provide an opportunity for preserving the favorable features while improving membrane permeability and, consequently, the AUC following oral dosing. This concept arose from observations made with C-28 amine derivatives where shielding of the amine moieties by installing adjacent alkyl substituents led to improved oral exposure.(20)
    Carbamate 23 and urea 24 are C-17 amine derivatives that preserve the length of the side chain present in 4, but both compounds showed diminished potency toward all of the screening viruses when compared with 4. The introduction of an amide moiety, as in 25 and 26, allowed the linker to be shortened by 1 and 2 atoms, respectively. While 25 exhibited similar antiviral properties to 23 and 24, the shorter analogue 26 displayed a much improved antiviral profile and was comparable to that of 4. In addition, the PK properties of carbamate 23 in the rat following oral dosing represented a 1.5-fold improvement in the AUC0–24h when compared with 4, while the AUC0–6h of 26 was 5-fold higher than that of 4 and was comparable to that of 2. Amide 26 combined both the targeted virological and rat PK profiles but, while stable during incubation with RLM with a t1/2 value of >120 min, unfortunately suffered from unacceptably poor metabolic stability in HLM, with a t1/2 of just 9 min. The introduction of an alkyl group α- to the amide moiety had a positive effect on the human metabolic stability, extending the t1/2 to 15.2 min for the methyl derivative 27 and to 90 min for the isopropyl analogue 28. However, these structural modifications had a detrimental impact on the inhibitory activity toward polymorphic viruses. An in vitro biotransformation study conducted with amide 26 revealed that the major metabolites were a consequence of oxidation either in the C-17 side chain or in the triterpenoid core, while no products of amide hydrolysis were detected. It was hypothesized that compounds with increased polarity might exert a positive effect on HLM stability while maintaining antiviral potency and targeted oral exposure in the rat. To that end, the C-17 amine derivatives 1 and 29 exhibited high metabolic stability in HLM (t1/2 > 120 min) and excellent potency toward both WT and polymorphic viruses as well as demonstrating significantly higher oral exposure in rats when compared with 4 (4.5- and 3-fold for 1 and 29, respectively). In accord with previous observations, the shorter chain analogue 1, which incorporated an ethyl linker between the two amino groups, demonstrated 2–3-fold better antiviral potency and superior oral exposure compared to amine 29, which is configured with a propyl linker.
    Compound 1, with EC50 values of 1.9, 2.7, and 13 nM toward the WT, V370A, and ΔV370 viruses, respectively, represented a 5-, 200-, and >1000-fold improvement in potency toward each virus over the first generation MI, 2. In the presence of human serum, 1 exhibited a modest ∼5-fold reduction in antiviral potency, a reflection of moderate serum protein binding (86.1% binding to human serum albumin as determined by an ultracentrifugation assay, Table 3).(8) Furthermore, the plasma AUC0–24h for 1 following oral administration to rats was 14,198 nM·h, exposure comparable to that recorded for 2. On the basis of the antiviral potency, polymorphic coverage, low serum shift, and good PK properties, 1 met the requirements of a potential second generation MI. However, because 1 was one of the first of two C-17 amines prepared, it was decided to further explore the SARs associated with this series in search of further modifications that might identify a candidate with an enhanced profile. The optimal ethyl linkage between the two nitrogen atoms was maintained throughout the survey. The relevance of the TMD moiety was evaluated by first replacing it with slightly more basic cyclic amines such as morpholine 30 (pKa = 8.2) and 4,4-difluoropiperidine 31 (pKa = 8.5).(29−31) In each case, there was a 3–6-fold loss of antiviral potency toward all three screening viruses. A noncyclic terminal amine was also evaluated, of which the hydroxyethylamine derivative 32 exhibited potency toward the WT virus comparable to 1 but was significantly less potent toward the polymorphic variants.
    Replacing the nitrogen atom in the ring of 1 with a carbon, as illustrated by tetrahydro-2H-thiopyran dioxide 33, preserved potency toward the WT virus but resulted in a pronounced 10-fold shift of potency in the presence of HS. The cyclic sulfonamide variant 34 conserved potency toward the WT and V370A viruses but was a weaker inhibitor of the ΔV370 polymorphic virus. Increasing the size of the cyclic amine, as in 35, was tolerated, but the increased lipophilicity resulted in a deleterious effect in the presence of HS, with a 9.7-fold shift in the EC50 value. Moving either the terminal amine (36) or the sulfone (37) moiety outside of the ring system was well tolerated with respect to antiviral potency, which extended to the polymorphic viruses, and these modifications were associated with a modest EC50 shift in the presence of HS. The promising antiviral profile of the piperidine-based sulfone 37 provided the basis for the preparation of the topologically related piperazine sufonamide 38 which exhibited potency toward WT and V370A viruses comparable to 1 but was less potent toward the ΔV370 virus.
    The piperazine ring of 38 facilitated the exploration of other substituents in the heterocycle but, as illustrated by ethyl derivative 39 and isopropyl analogue 40, the larger substituents provided no specific advantage. Analogues incorporating the piperidine mimics explored by 41–44 displayed good antiviral potency toward both WT and the ΔV370 virus. However, in general, the sulfonamides 38 and 41–44 suffered from more pronounced shifts in potency in the presence of HS (7.2–14.4-fold). Interestingly, the bicyclic compounds sulfone 45 and sulfonamide 46 exhibited potency toward the WT and polymorphic viruses with HS shifts that were comparable to 1, while the cyclic sulfoximine 47 offered a similar overall profile.(32) Finally, as observed previously, the introduction of a fluorine atom to the phenyl ring ortho- to the carboxylic acid moiety (48) was also well tolerated.(17)
    In rat PK studies, sulfone 36 and bicyclic sulfonamide 46 displayed lower plasma AUC values (4243 and 7077 nM·h, respectively) than 1 (14,198 nM·h), while compounds 38, 45, 47, and 48 all displayed higher AUC values (28562, 27032, 20745, and 24276 nM·h, respectively) that exceeded those of 1 following an identical dose. However, the higher plasma AUC values were accompanied by considerable inter-animal variability, as reflected by the standard deviations indicated for each of these four compounds in Table 1, a phenomenon that might be attributable to solubility issues compromising exposure. While all five compounds 1, 38, 45, 47, and 48 presented similar aqueous solubility with values of <1 μg/mL, the solubility in biorelevant fluids exhibited some variation. For example, the fluoro analogue 48 showed solubility values of 0.14 and 0.33 mg/mL in fasted simulated intestinal fluid (FaSSIF, pH = 6.5) and fed simulated intestinal fluid (FeSSIF, pH = 5.0), respectively.(33) In contrast, 1 displayed higher solubility in FaSSIF (0.28 mg/mL) and in FeSSIF (1.02 mg/mL). These solubility differences in FeSSIF and FaSSIF, although modest, are very likely underestimates because 48 was evaluated as an amorphous solid while 1 was crystalline. Difficulties in developing suitable formulations for 38, 45, 47, and 48 that would address the PK variability prevented further consideration of these compounds for advancement.
    Compound 1 emerged as the best candidate as a result of its potent antiviral activity toward both WT and polymorphic viruses, a low fold-shift in the presence of HS, and favorable PK properties in the rat. In addition, 1 was tested for mutagenicity in a bacterial reverse mutation assay (Salmonella typhimurium strains TA98 and TA100) with and without metabolic activation (Aroclor 1254-induced rat liver S9). Over the concentration range of 5–5000 μg/plate, 1 was not mutagenic at concentrations up to 1600 μg/plate, conditions under which precipitation or cytotoxicity was not observed. In a micronucleus assay with evaluation by flow cytometry, 1 was not genotoxic at concentrations of 12 and 17 μg/mL in the absence and presence of metabolic activation, respectively. An in vitro safety evaluation of 1 against a broad panel of ion channels and enzyme and receptor binding assays indicated no significant off-target liabilities. Because 1 contains a basic amine, the potential for inducing phospholipidosis was explored using a predictive in silico method that indicated no potential for this potentially problematic side effect, a prediction subsequently confirmed with in vivo studies.(34) The promising properties of 1 led to it being subjected to extensive in vitro virological profiling and in vitro and in vivo pharmacokinetic assessment.
    Table 2 compiles the potency of 1 against an expanded panel of common viruses with polymorphisms in the Gag protein that are resistant to 2, with EC50 values for 1 against all viruses below 15 nM. The fold difference (FD) between 1 and 2 for each virus is also noted and ranges from 3.7-fold for the Q369H variant to >770-fold for the ΔV370 virus. In addition, 1 displayed a mean IC50 value of 3.9 ± 3.4 nM when tested against a selection of 87 clinically relevant isolates representative of ∼96.5% of the sequence variability existing across the 362–370 amino acid region of the Gag polyprotein in subtype B viruses.(8) Consistent with the profile of MIs, 1 showed reduced activity (EC50 = 1.48 μM) toward the A364 V virus, which, although not found in clinical circulation, is selected by 2 both in vitro and in vivo and which compromises antiviral activity with EC50 values of >10 μM.(35−37) Adding further confirmation to the MI MOA, 1 inhibited the final step in the virus maturation process, cleavage of the capsid (CA) precursor p25 to capsid p24 and spacer peptide 1 (SP1), in a time-dependent manner in both virus-like particles (VLPs) and infected cells, a biochemical profile comparable to 2.(8,38) As shown in Table 2, 1 demonstrated comparable binding affinity to 2 toward a WT HIV-1 viral-like particle (VLP) (uncleaved Gag polyprotein, i.e., the immature form of the HIV-1 virus) that was largely maintained for the same VLP incorporating either a V370A or a V362I sequence change. However, binding affinity was weaker toward a VLP with a single change representing the ΔV370 polymorph. In contrast, the affinity of 2 for the VLPs incorporating the V370A, V362I, and ΔV370 changes was more significantly attenuated (Table 2). Interestingly, while the affinity of 2 for the A364 V VLPs was too weak to be measured, the affinity of 1, although attenuated, was measurable, with a Kd of 98 ± 13 nM. An assessment of the binding kinetics in VLPs revealed similar dissociation half-lives for 1 (t1/2 = 41 min) and 2 (t1/2 = 51 min) toward the WT sequence, while the dissociation kinetics of 2 from both the V370A and ΔV370 sequences were rapid (t1/2 ≤ 3 min). In contrast, the dissociation half-life of 1 from the V370A sequence was similar to WT (t1/2 = 36 min), while for the ΔV370 sequence, the t1/2 of 46 min suggested a slower association rate as the source of the more substantial difference in binding affinity (∼10-fold) measured for this VLP compared to WT. Compound 1 maintained comparable potency toward viruses resistant to antiviral agents with different MOAs, including protease, reverse transcriptase and integrase inhibitors, with EC50 values that were comparable to the WT virus, indicating a lack of cross-resistance with MIs, an important clinical property.
    Table 2. Antiviral Activity (EC50)a toward HIV-1 Viruses Containing Common Naturally-Occurring Polymorphisms in the Gag Polyprotein and Binding Affinity (Kd) toward a WT HIV-1 Viral-Like Particle (VLP)(38)

     LANLb (%)12FDc12

    Values are means from experiments performed a minimum of three times (n ≥ 3).

    b

    Percent occurrence in the Los Alamos National Laboratories database.

    c

    FD: Fold difference between EC50 of 1 and 2 for each virus.

    The low aqueous solubility and high lipophilicity of 1 precluded a definitive in vitro assessment of membrane permeability; consequently, information could only be extracted from in vivo studies. The potential for CYP 3A4 induction or inhibition by 1 was low based on in vitro studies, but the compound could not be properly evaluated at higher concentrations due to poor solubility in the incubation media. Compound 1 was stable in the presence of mouse, rat, dog, and human NADPH-fortified LMs, with t1/2 values of >120 min. In cynomolgus monkey LMs, however, 1 exhibited a high metabolic turnover in the presence of added NADPH, with a short t1/2 of 11 min. An overprediction of clearance (CL) from cynomolgus monkey microsomal preparations was observed compared to the in vivo results. Similar results were also observed after incubation with suspensions of fresh primary hepatocytes, with t1/2 values of >120 min in all species with the exception of cynomolgus monkey cells (data not shown).
    Although the metabolism of 1 could not be quantified using in vitro systems, metabolites were identified by mass spectrometric analysis using a 14C labeled analogue of 1, [14C]-1 (Figure 2). In vitro metabolism of 1 involved oxidation, N-dealkylation, aromatic decarboxylation, and glucuronidation of the carboxylic acid moiety. No unique metabolites were found in human-derived systems in vitro, and no GSH adducts were detected in any samples. Compound 1 was the main drug-related compound detected in plasma from rats, dogs, and monkeys following oral administration of the drug. Minor amounts of the metabolites Met1 and Met2 (mono-oxidation products), Met3 (N-dealkylation), and Met4 (acyl glucuronide) were also detected in rat, dogs, and monkeys. Although acyl glucuronide formation was observed in vivo, 1 was stable in liver microsomes fortified with UDPGA. CYP 3A4 is the primary enzyme involved in the oxidative metabolism of 1 based on in vitro metabolic reaction phenotyping studies using individually expressed recombinant CYP 450 enzymes (data not shown). Compound 1 was stable in fresh human plasma at 37 °C for 2 h. The blood-to-plasma concentration ratio was 0.68 in human blood and ranged from 0.65 to 0.68 in the three animal species studied. Protein binding could not be determined by equilibrium dialysis, possibly due to aggregation of compound in the media which prevented permeability through the dialysis membrane. Consequently, an ultracentrifugation method was used to determine protein binding for this compound under conditions where membrane permeability was not an issue.(39) In this assay, 1 (5.3 nM) was determined to be 86.1% bound to human serum proteins and 78–94% bound to the serum proteins of the four animal species studied, data that are compiled in Table 3. This degree of protein binding to human serum is consistent with the rightward shift in antiviral potency observed in cell culture in the presence of 40% human serum.(8)
    Table 3. Protein Binding of 1 in Different Species As Determined by an Ultracentrifugation Assay(39)
     mouseratdogmonkeyhuman
    % bound89.4 ± 4.285.9 ± 2.284.6 ± 4.878.4 ± 3 0.286.1 ± 0.4
    The pharmacokinetic parameters of 1 in different species are detailed in Table 4. Following IV dosing to mouse, rat, cynomolgus monkey, and dog, the total plasma clearance (CLTp) was low (0.13 to 2.2 mL/min/kg). Extravascular distribution of 1 was observed in the mouse and rat, where the steady-state volume of distribution (Vss) was 0.82 and 1.1 L/kg, respectively, but a lower Vss was observed in the dog (0.36 L/kg) and cynomolgus monkey (0.43 L/kg). Compound 1 exhibited low to moderate oral bioavailability (F) in the animal species tested. The absolute oral bioavailability from a precipitation-resistant solution (80% 50 mM pH = 3 citrate buffer, 20% captisol) was 27% in mice (5 mg/kg), 26% in rats (5 mg/kg), 9% in dogs (2 mg/kg), and 4% in the cynomolgus monkey (2 mg/kg). Figure 3 shows the concentration versus time curves for all species, with a delayed Tmax following oral administration observed in the rat, a long t1/2 in the dog, and low oral exposure in the cynomolgus monkey, which can be explained by the poor metabolic stability in LMs from this species. There are several potential causes for the observed low oral bioavailability of 1. Because 1 has low plasma clearance in vivo and is stable in LMs and hepatocytes, metabolic instability is most likely not a cause for the low bioavailability of this compound in the mouse, rat, and dog. Poor permeability with associated P-glycoprotein (P-gp) involvement is often a cause of low bioavailability in pharmaceutical compounds,(40) but because 1 displays the behavioral characteristics associated with solubility-limited absorption, developing a formulation compatible with optimal absorption of 1 could improve the low oral exposure. In addition, on the basis of the different solubility of 1 in the FaSSIF and FeSSIF studies, pH or food effects may lead to a change in the absorption properties. The potential causes for the low oral bioavailability of 1 were investigated in a series of experiments conducted in mice, rats, and dogs.
    Table 4. In Vivo Pharmacokinetic Parameters for 1 in the Mouse, Rat, Dog, and Cynomolgus Monkey
    speciesRAadose (mg/kg)formulationCmax (μM)tmax (h)AUC(0–inf) (μM·h)t1/2 (h)CLTp (mL/min/kg)Vss (L/kg)F (%)
    mouseIV1   21.68.91.10.82 
     PO5solution2.79328.9   26.8
    MDR1 a/bPO5 4.02365.5   45.0

     PO5solution1.2 ± 0.176.0 ± 0.014.2 ± 1.1   26 ± 5
     PO5+ elacridar1.8 ± 0.497.3 ± 1.247.4 ± 8.5   63 ± 6.1
     IDb5 1.7 ± 0.091.0 ± 0.019.9 ± 2.9   36 ± 5.3

     PO5microsuspension + famotidine4.04 ± 2.1713.5 ± 12.2236 ± 144   26 ± 16
         
    cynomolgus monkeyIV1   13.6 ± 4.08.6 ± 0.51.9 ± 0.50.43 ± 0.01 
     PO2solution0.062 ± 0.0143.3 ± 1.21.0 ± 0.3   4 ± 0.2
    a

    Route of administration.

    b

    ID: intraduodenal.

    Mouse and rat in vivo studies were conducted to determine if 1 may be a P-gp substrate. In the mouse, a MDR1 a/b (P-gp) knockout model was used.(41) Elacridar (GF120918A), an in vivo P-gp and breast cancer resistance protein (BCRP) inhibitor that is commonly used to determine transporter involvement, was exploited for evaluation of 1 in the rat.(42) The results of these two studies are compiled in Table 4 and shown in Figure 4. Higher oral exposure was observed in both the mouse P-gp knockout animals and Elacridar-treated rats, suggesting that the absorption of 1 may be compromised by P-gp-mediated efflux in the gastrointestinal tract.
    The dog was selected as the most appropriate model for an evaluation of different drug formulations and the effects of food and pH on intestinal absorption based on experience with this species.(43,44) Oral dosing of 1 as a microsuspension (particle size of 8 μm) to pentagastrin-treated dogs (to simulate the lower human gastric pH in this species) provided an absolute oral bioavailability of 26% from a 5 mg/kg dose, significantly higher than that achieved from solution dosing (9%).(43) The tmax and oral half-life values were similar to that following solution-based dosing (Figure 5). To investigate whether the increase in bioavailability was due to the effects of pentagastrin on pH, a dog PK study was conducted with 1 following pretreatment with famotidine to increase the gastric pH.(43) Following oral administration of 1 (5 mg/kg) as a microsuspension to fasted dogs pretreated with famotidine, similar oral exposure was observed compared to the fasted leg where drug was dosed as a microsuspension following pentagastrin pretreatment (Table 4 and Figure 5). The results from this study with famotidine suggest that the effect of changes in gastric pH on the oral absorption of 1 is minimal.
    A food-effect study was also performed in dogs at a dose of 5 mg/kg of 1 administered as a microsuspension after pretreatment of the animals with pentagastrin and following a high-fat meal.(44) This study revealed a significant difference in the PK profile between fasted and fed dogs following oral administration of a suspension of 1. The oral bioavailability from a suspension formulation in pentagastrin-treated dogs was increased from 26% in fasted dogs to 67% in fed dogs, clearly demonstrating the potential for this compound to be well absorbed (Table 4 and Figure 5).
    In summary, the oral bioavailability of 1 dosed as a solution varies depending on the preclinical species. In addition, the plasma exposure of 1 is influenced by formulation, improved bioavailability is observed when 1 is dosed as a suspension, demostrating the ability of 1 to be absorbed from a solid-dosage form. Absorption of 1 was also improved in the presence of food, indicating the potential for food effect.
    The efficacious human dose of 1 was projected such that plasma levels sufficient to inhibit 96% of subtype B polymorphs would be achieved.(8) On the basis of the antiviral potency of 1 using a reverse transcriptase-based assay, a plasma concentration of 281 nM, estimated to be 3-fold above the EC90 determined in the presence of HS, was projected to achieve this target. Therefore, following administration of 1 to humans, a Cmin value of 281 nM should be maintained to ensure antiviral activity. The human volume of distribution (0.31 L/kg) and blood clearance (0.36 mL/min/kg) following IV administration were predicted by allometric scaling of mouse, rat, dog, and cynomolgus monkey PK parameters.(45) Predictions of blood clearance could not be obtained by scaling of in vitro intrinsic clearance values using HLMs or hepatocytes due to the high level of stability of 1 in these preparations. On the basis of this information and by using the average oral bioavailability of a solution dose in preclinical species (16%), an efficacious dose of 120 mg per 70 kg adult for 1 was predicted. At this dose, the trough concentration of 1 projected at 24 h following oral dosing is 281 nM, while the AUC0–24 h was estimated to be 18.8 μM·h. These predictions are based on dosing 1 as a solution formulation. Pharmaceutics studies with a microsuspension of 1 in the dog indicated the potential for solid dosage administration. Also, because the projected human t1/2 for 1 is 11.2 h, some accumulation of compound may occur following daily drug administration, but this was not taken into account in projecting the human efficacious dose.
    Compound 1 was evaluated as monotherapy in a phase IIa clinical trial conducted in treatment-naive and treatment-experienced patients infected with HIV-1 subtype-B virus. Subjects received QD doses of 1 ranging from 5 to 120 mg. Compound 1 was safe and well-tolerated and demonstrated >1 log10 copies/mL reduction in viral RNA for doses ≥40 mg.(46) In a 28 day clinical study conducted in subjects infected with HIV-1 subtypes B and C, 1 was administered as a part of a dual treatment regimen with the protease inhibitor atazanavir (ATV) ± ritonavir (RTV). The VLRs achieved for the 40–120 mg QD dose groups were independent of pre-existing polymorphisms and comparable to a control patient cohort treated with a standard-of-care (SOC) regimen comprising tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (300 mg), emtricitabine (200 mg), and ATV ± RTV (300 mg/100 mg), demonstrating the utility of 1 as an oral, QD HIV-1 MI with broad polymorphic coverage.(46) However, due to gastrointestinal intolerability and treatment-emergent drug resistance observed during a 24-week dose-finding study conducted in treatment-naive-patients, the development of 1 was halted in favor of progression of newer generation MIs with further improvements to polymorphic coverage.(47)

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    GSK3532795, formerly known as BMS-955176 (1), is a C-3 benzoic acid-based, C-17 amine derivative of betulinic acid (3) shown to be a potent, orally active second-generation MI. The C-3 benzoic acid preserved the MOA observed with first-generation MIs while conferring a much lower shift in the EC50 value in the presence of human serum. The introduction of basic amines in the C-28, C-17 position of the triterpenoid core broadened the polymorphic coverage of the chemotype while careful modulation of the basicity of the C-17 side chain was critical to achieving the desired pharmacokinetic profile. Allometric scaling of mouse, rat, dog, and cynomolgus monkey PK parameters was used to estimate an efficacious dose of 120 mg per 70 kg adult, which led to the evaluation of 1 in the clinical setting, where 1 demonstrated proof of concept.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemistry Materials and Methods

    Unless otherwise stated, solvents and reagents were used directly as obtained from commercial sources, and reactions were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere. Flash chromatography was performed by using pre-packed columns from Teledyne Isco and Biotage or using Silica Gel 60 (0.040-0.063 mm) from EM Science as stationary phase. The purity of all new compounds was determined using preparative high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), and in each case, unless otherwise indicated, it was ≥95%. HPLC was performed using the following methods. Method 1: column, Phenomenex Luna C8, 10 μm, 50 mm × 250 mm; 90% H2O, 10% CH3CN, 0.1% TFA to 10% H2O, 90% CH3CN, 0.1% TFA; 10 min gradient; 100 mL/min flow rate. Method 2: column, Waters Xbridge Phenyl, 5 μm, 30 mm × 100 mm; 90% H2O, 10% CH3CN, 0.1% TFA to 10% H2O, 90% CH3CN, 0.1% TFA; 8 min gradient; 50 mL/min. Method 3: column, Waters Sunfire C18, 5 μm, 30 mm × 150 mm; 90% H2O:10% CH3CN, 0.1% TFA to H2O, 90% CH3CN, 0.1% TFA; 8 min gradient; 50 mL/min. Method 4: column, Waters Sunfire C18, 5 μm, 30 mm × 150 mm; 5% CH3CN:95% H2O:10 mM NH4OAc to 95% CH3CN:5% H2O:10 mM NH4OAc; 8 min gradient; 50 mL/min flow rate. Method 5: column, Waters Sunfire C18, 5 μm, 30 mm × 150 mm; 90% H2O:10% CH3CN:0.1% TFA to 10% H2O:90% CH3CN:0.1% TFA; 50 mL/min; 15 min gradient; 50 mL/min. Method 6: column, Waters Sunfire C18, 5 μm, 30 mm × 150 mm; 90% H2O:10% MeOH:0.1% TFA to 10% H2O:90% MeOH:0.1% TFA; 10 min gradient; 50 mL/min. HPLC Method 7: column, Waters Sunfire C18, 5 μm, 30 mm × 150 mm; 90% H2O:10% MeOH:0.1% TFA to 10% H2O:90% MeOH:0.1% TF; 15 min gradient; 50 mL/min. Method: column, Waters Sunfire C18, 5 μm, 30 mm × 150 mm; 90% H2O:10% CH3CN:0.1% TFA to 10% H2O:90% CH3CN:0.1% TFA; 15 min gradient; 50 mL/min. Method 9: column, Waters-YMC OBD 20 mm × 100 mm S5; 5% MeOH:95% H2O:10 mM NH4OAc to 95% MeOH:5% H2O:10 mM NH4OAc; 10 min gradient; 25 mL/min. All liquid chromatography (LC) data were recorded on a Shimadzu LC-10AS liquid chromatograph using a SPD-10AV UV–vis detector with mass spectrometry (MS) data determined using a Micromass Platform for LC in electrospray mode. LCMS analyses were performed using one of the following conditions. Method 1: column, Phenomenex Luna C18, 5 μm, 3.0 mm × 50 mm; 95% H2O, 5% MeOH, 10 mM NH4OAc to 5% H2O, 95% MeOH, 10 mM NH4OAc; 2 min gradient; 4 mL/min flow rate. Method 2: column, Phenomenex Luna C18, 3 μm, 2.0 mm × 30 mm; 95% H2O, 5% CH3CN, 10 mM NH4OAc to 5% H2O, 95% CH3CN, 10 mM NH4OAc; 2 min gradient; 1 mL/min flow rate. Method 3: column, Phenomenex Luna C18, 3 μm, 2.0 mm × 30 mm; 90% H2O, 10% MeOH, 0.1% TFA to 10% H2O, 90% MeOH, 0.1% TFA; 2 min gradient; 1 mL/min flow rate. Method 4: column, Xbridge Phenyl 2.1 mm × 50 mm 2.5 μm; 90% H2O, 10% MeOH, 0.1% TFA to 10% H2O, 90% MeOH, 0.1% TFA; 2 min gradient; 0.8 mL/min flow rate. Method 5: column, Xbridge Phenyl 2.1 mm × 50 mm 2.5 μm; 90% H2O, 10% MeOH, 0.1% TFA to 10% H2O, 90% MeOH, 0.1% TFA; 2 min gradient; 0.6 mL/min flow rate. Method 6: column, Phenomenex Luna C18, 3 μm, 2.0 mm × 30 mm; 90% H2O, 10% CH3CN, 0.1% TFA to 10% H2O, 90% CH3CN, 0.1% TFA; 2 min gradient; 1 mL/min. Method 7: column, Phenomenex-Luna 2.0 mm × 50 mm 3 μm; 90% H2O, 10% MeOH, 0.1% TFA to 10% H2O, 90% MeOH, 0.1% TFA; 1 min gradient; 0.8 mL/min flow rate. Method 8: column, Phenomenex-Luna 2.0 mm × 50 mm 3 μm; 90% H2O, 10% MeOH, 0.1% TFA to 10% H2O, 90% MeOH, 0.1% TFA; 4 min gradient; 0.8 mL/min flow rate. Method 8: column, YMC Pack Pro C18 (19 mm × 150 mm); gradient: 90% A, 0 min; 90% A 0–5 min; 90–0% A, 5–20 min; 0% A, 20–25 min; 0–90% A, 25–30 min (A = H2O, 0.1% HCl, B = CH3CN, 0.1% HCl); 15 mL/min flow rate. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX-500f at 500 MHz (or a Bruker AV 400 MHz, Bruker DPX-300B or Varian Gemini 300 at 300 MHz, as stated). The chemical shifts were reported in ppm on the δ scale relative to δTMS = 0. The following internal references were used for the residual protons in the following solvents: CDCl3 (δH 7.27), CD3OD (δH 3.30), AcOH-d4 (δH 11.6, 2.07), and CH3CN-d3 (δH 1.94). Standard acronyms were employed to describe the multiplicity patterns: s (singlet), br. s (broad singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet), q (quartet), m (multiplet), b (broad), app (apparent). The coupling constant (J) is in hertz.

    General Procedure for the C-28 Amide Formation and Hydrolysis

    To a solution of methyl 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-(chlorocarbonyl)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoate(18) in ClCH2CH2Cl or CH2Cl2 (0.02–0.15 M) was added Hunig’s base (3–5 equiv), the amine (1–10 equiv), and DMAP (0.03–0.1 equiv). The mixture was stirred at rt for 2–72 h, diluted with 1 N HCl or H2O, and extracted with CH2Cl2. The organic layer was dried over Na2SO4, the drying agent was removed by filtration, and the filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by flash chromatography or was directly used in the next step with no additional purification. Note: The same reaction conditions can be used without DMAP to successfully form the corresponding amides.

    General Procedures for Hydrolysis of the Benzoate Ester

    (a) The ester was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane and aqueous 1N or 10N NaOH in excess (5–20 equiv) was added and the mixture heated to 50–85 °C. The reaction progress was monitored by LC/MS and after heating for 2–24 h, all starting material was consumed. The mixture was cooled to rt and was either purified by preparative HPLC directly or was made acidic by the dropwise addition of 1 N HCl and the product crystallized from 1,4-dioxane/H2O or 1,4-dioxane/MeOH/H2O.
    (b) The ester was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane and H2O (4:1 or 5:1 dioxane:H2O or THF:H2O) was added followed by LiOH·H2O (3–12 equiv). The reaction mixture was heated to 50–85 °C and was monitored by LC/MS for complete consumption of the starting material. After 2–24 h, the mixture was cooled to rt and was either purified by preparative HPLC or was made acidic by dropwise addition of 1 N HCl and the product crystallized from 1,4-dioxane/H2O or dioxane/MeOH/H2O.

    4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-((3-(1,1-Dioxido-4-thiomorpholinyl)propyl)carbamoyl)-1-isopropenyl-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoic Acid (6)

    The title compound was prepared following the general procedures described above for the C-28 amide formation and hydrolysis using 4-(3-aminopropyl)thiomorpholine 1,1-dioxide as the reactant amine. The product was isolated as a white solid (27 mg, 95% HPLC purity, 0.035 mmol, 65% yield). LCMS: m/e 733.44 (M + H)+, 2.11 min (method 1). 1H NMR (500 MHz, AcOH-d4) δ ppm 8.03 (d, J = 8.24 Hz, 2 H), 7.30 (d, J = 8.24 Hz, 2 H), 5.37 (d, J = 4.58 Hz, 1 H), 4.78 (s, 1 H), 4.65 (s, 1 H), 3.85 (br s, 4 H), 3.60 (br s, 4 H), 3.49–3.33 (m, 2 H), 3.33–3.25 (m, 2 H), 3.15 (td, J = 11.06, 10 4.73 Hz, 1 H), 2.66–2.54 (m, 1 H), 2.26–2.13 (m, 2 H), 1.74 (s, 3 H), 2.03–1.09 (m, 21 H), 1.08 (s, 3 H), 1.07 (s, 3 H), 1.06 (s, 3 H), 1.01 (s, 3 H), 0.99 (s, 3 H).

    4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-((2-(1,1-Dioxido-4-thiomorpholinyl)ethyl)carbamoyl)-1-isopropenyl-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoic Acid (7)

    The title compound was prepared following the general procedures described above for the C-28 amide formation and hydrolysis using N-(2-aminoethyl)thiomorpholine 1,1-dioxide as the reactant amine. The product was isolated as a white solid (39 mg, 95% HPLC purity, 0.052 mmol, 69%). LCMS: m/e 720.18 (M + H)+, 2.15 min (method 1). 1H NMR (500 MHz, AcOH-d4) δ ppm 8.03 (d, J = 8.24 Hz, 2 H), 7.30 (d, J = 8.24 Hz, 2 H), 5.37(d, J = 4.58 Hz, 1 H), 4.78 (s, 1 H), 4.65 (s, 1 H), 3.83 (br s, 4 H), 3.81–3.67 (m, 2H), 3.56 (br s, 4 H), 3.46–3.31 (m, 2 H), 3.14 (td, J = 10.91, 4.12 Hz, 1 H), 2.60–2.48 (m, 1 H), 2.26–2.11 (m, 2 H), 1.74 (s, 3 H), 2.03–1.09 (m, 19 H), 1.08 (s, 3 H), 1.06 (s, 3 H), 1.04 (s, 3 H), 1.01 (s, 3 H), 0.99 (s, 3 H).

    (1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aR,11bR,13aR,13bR)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-Pentamethyl-9-oxo-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)icosahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysene-3a-carboxylic Acid (9)

    To suspension of 8 (20 g, 45.2 mmol) in CH3CN (200 mL) and CH2Cl2 (300 mL) was added 4 Å molecular sieves (5 g), and the mixture was stirred for 10 min at rt. To the mixture was added NMO (15.88 g, 136 mmol) followed by TPAP (0.794 g, 2.26 mmol). After 16 h of stirring, additional NMO (2 g) and TPAP (0.08g) were added and the mixture was stirred for an additional 7 h. It was then filtered through a pad of silica gel and Celite, which was washed sequentially with CH2Cl2 and a 4:1 mixture of EtOAc:hexanes. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure and the residue purified by flash chromatography using a gradient of 15–20% EtOAc in hexanes. Fractions containing the major isolate were combined and concentrated under reduced pressure to give (1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aR,11bR,13aR,13bR)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-9-oxo-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)icosahydro-3aH-cyclopenta[a]chrysene-3a-carbaldehyde (17.6 g, 40.1 mmol, 89% yield) as a white foam. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 9.68 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1H), 4.77 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 4.66–4.63 (m, 1H), 2.89 (td, J = 11.2, 5.8 Hz, 1H), 2.56–2.36 (m, 2H), 2.16–2.03 (m, 2H), 1.97–1.84 (m, 2H), 1.71 (s, 3H), 1.08 (s, 3H), 1.03 (s, 3H), 1.00 (s, 3H), 0.97 (s, 3H), 0.94 (s, 3H), 1.83–0.87 (m, 18H).
    To a solution of (1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aR,11bR,13aR,13bR)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-9-oxo-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)icosahydro-3aH-cyclopenta[a]chrysene-3a-carbaldehyde (17.6 g, 36.1 mmol) in t-BuOH (100 mL) was added 2-methyl-2-butene (40 mL, 476 mmol). A solution of NaClO2 (15 g, 133 mmol) and NaH2PO4·H2O (25 g, 181 mmol) in H2O (200 mL) was added dropwise over 1.25 h, and the mixture was stirred at rt for an additional 45 min, at which point all starting material had been consumed (monitored by TLC). The mixture was diluted with satd NH4Cl solution (100 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (3 × 125 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by flash chromatography using a gradient of 10–50% EtOAc in hexanes to afford 9 (16.41 g, 36.1 mmol, 100% yield) as a white foam. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 10.02 (br s, 1H), 4.75 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 4.64–4.61 (m, 1H), 3.02 (td, J = 10.8, 4.8 Hz, 1H), 2.55–2.36 (m, 3H), 2.33–2.19 (m, 2H), 2.08–1.86 (m, 4H), 1.70 (s, 3H), 1.08 (s, 3H), 1.02 (s, 3H), 1.00 (s, 3H), 0.98 (s, 3H), 0.93 (s, 3H), 1.82–0.90 (m, 15H).

    (1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aR,11bR,13aR,13bR)-Benzyl 5a,5b,8,8,11a-Pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-9-(trifluoromethylsulfonyloxy)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysene-3a-carboxylate (10)

    To a mixture of 9 (14.5 g, 31.9 mmol) and K2CO3 (8.81 g, 63.8 mmol) in DMF (150 mL) was added benzyl bromide (3.98 mL, 33.5 mmol). The mixture was heated to 60 °C for 16 h, then was cooled to rt and 200 mL of H2O was added. The precipitate that formed were collected by filtration and washed with excess H2O to give (1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aR,13aR,13bR)-benzyl 5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-9-oxo-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)icosahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysene-3a-carboxylate as a white solid (17.37g, 31.9 mmol, 100% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.40–7.29 (m, 5H), 5.20–5.08 (m, 2H), 4.73 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 4.61 (s, 1H), 3.03 (td, J = 11.1, 4.7 Hz, 1H), 2.53–2.45 (m, 1H), 2.44–2.36 (m, 1H), 2.29 (dt, J = 12.6, 3.2 Hz, 1H), 2.26–2.19 (m, 1H), 1.95–1.84 (m, 3H), 1.69 (s, 3H), 1.07 (s, 3H), 1.02 (s, 3H), 0.96 (s, 3H), 0.91 (s, 3H), 1.76–0.86 (m, 17H), 0.80 (s, 3H).
    A solution of (1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aR,11bR,13aR,13bR)-benzyl 5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-9-oxo-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)icosahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysene-3a-carboxylate (20 g, 36.7 mmol) in THF (150 mL) was cooled to −78 °C, and a solution of KHMDS (0.5 M in toluene) (147 mL, 73.4 mmol) was added. The mixture was stirred for 20 min at −78 °C, and a solution of N-phenyl-bis(trifluoromethanesulfonimide) (17.22 g, 47.7 mmol) in THF (50 mL) was added via cannula over 5 min. The resulting red reaction mixture was stirred at −78 °C for 2 h, at which point TLC showed only a trace amount of starting material remaining. The ice bath was removed, and reaction mixture was quenched with H2O (200 mL) and stirred to ambient temperature. The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (2 × 150 mL) and the combined organic layers washed with brine, dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated to give a yellow foam. The crude material was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (50 mL), and MeOH (200 mL) was added to effect a white precipitate which was collected by filtration and washed with MeOH to give 10 as a white solid. The mother liquor was concentrated and the crystallization process was repeated. The two batches of product were combined to give 10 (23.27 g, 34.4 mmol, 94% yield) as white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.39–7.36 (m, 4H), 7.36–7.32 (m, 1H), 5.56 (dd, J = 6.7, 1.8 Hz, 1H), 5.14 (t, J = 1.0 Hz, 2H), 4.74 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 4.61 (dd, J = 2.1, 1.2 Hz, 1H), 3.04 (td, J = 11.0, 4.6 Hz, 1H), 2.30 (dt, J = 12.6, 3.2 Hz, 1H), 2.27–2.20 (m, 1H), 2.15 (dd, J = 17.1, 6.7 Hz, 1H), 1.96–1.83 (m, 2H), 1.77–1.70 (m, 2H), 1.69 (s, 3H), 1.62 (t, J = 11.3 Hz, 1H), 1.49–1.42 (m, 3H), 1.42–1.26 (m, 9H), 1.23–1.18 (m, 1H), 1.14 (d, J = 3.4 Hz, 1H), 1.12 (s, 3H), 1.02 (s, 3H), 0.96 (s, 3H), 0.90 (s, 3H), 0.79 (s, 3H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 175.7, 155.3, 150.5, 136.4, 128.5, 128.2, 128.1, 119.6, 117.1, 113.8, 109.6, 65.7, 56.5, 53.2, 49.3, 48.9, 46.9, 42.4, 40.5, 40.2, 38.2, 37.9, 36.9, 36.3, 33.2, 32.0, 30.5, 29.5, 27.4, 25.5, 21.4, 19.4, 19.4, 18.9, 16.2, 15.5, 14.6, 0.5.

    (1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-Benzyl 9-(4-(Methoxycarbonyl)phenyl)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysene-3a-carboxylate (11)

    To a solution of 10 (6.21 g, 9.18 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (25 mL) was added 2-propanol (25 mL) and H2O (15 mL), followed by Na2CO3.H2O (3.42 g, 27.5 mmol), 4-methoxycarbonylphenylboronic acid (2.478 g, 13.77 mmol), and Pd(PPh3)4 (0.318 g, 0.275 mmol). The flask was flushed with N2 and the mixture heated at reflux overnight before being cooled to rt and diluted with H2O (75 mL). The mixture was extracted with EtOAc (3 × 75 mL) and washed with brine (75 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was adsorbed onto silica gel and the product purified by flash chromatography using a gradient of 0–20% EtOAc in hexanes to give the title compound (4.16 g, 6.28 mmol, 68% yield) as a white foam. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ ppm 7.92 (d, J = 8.24 Hz, 2 H), 7.40–7.29 (m, 5 H), 7.19 (d, J = 8.24 Hz, 2 H), 5.28 (dd, J = 6.10, 1.83 Hz, 1 H), 5.19–5.07 (m, 2 H), 4.73 (d, J = 1.83 Hz, 1 H), 4.60 (s, 1 H), 3.90 (s, 3 H), 3.04 (td, J = 10.91, 4.73 Hz, 1 H), 2.20–2.32 (m, 2 H), 2.09 (dd, J = 17.24, 6.26 Hz, 1 H), 1.95–1.82 (m, 2 H), 1.69 (s, 3 H), 0.97 (s, 3 H), 0.95 (s, 3 H), 0.92 (s, 3 H), 0.91 (s, 3 H), 1.75–0.87 (m, 17 H), 0.82 (s, 3 H).

    (1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-9-(4-(Methoxycarbonyl)phenyl)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysene-3a-carboxylic Acid (12)

    To a solution of 11 (3.82 g, 5.76 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (100 mL) was added Et3N (1.285 mL, 9.22 mmol), tert-butyldimethylsilane (1.912 mL, 11.52 mmol), and PdOAc2 (0.647 g, 2.88 mmol). The mixture was heated to 60 °C under an atmosphere of N2 for 2 h, cooled to rt, and filtered through a pad of Celite and silica gel to remove the solids which were washed with 25% EtOAc in hexanes. The filtrate was concentrated under reduced pressure and treated with AcOH (25 mL), THF (10 mL) and H2O (3 mL). After stirring for 1 h, the solids formed were collected by filtration and washed with H2O to give (1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-tert-butyldimethylsilyl 9-(4-(methoxycarbonyl)phenyl)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysene-3a-carboxylate (3.62 g, 5.27 mmol, 91% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ ppm 7.94 (d, J = 8.28 Hz, 2 H), 7.21 (d, J = 8.28 Hz, 2 H), 5.30 (dd, J = 6.15, 1.63 Hz, 1 H), 4.75 (d, J = 1.76 Hz, 1 H), 4.62 (s, 1 H), 3.92 (s, 4 H), 3.08 (td, J = 10.92, 4.27 Hz, 1 H), 2.35–2.22 (m, 2 H), 2.17–2.06 (m, 1 H), 2.02–1.84 (m, 2 H), 1.71 (s, 3 H), 1.01 (s, 6 H), 0.99 (br s, 3 H), 0.98 (s, 9 H), 0.94 (s, 6 H), 1.78–0.90 (m, 16 H), 0.32–0.28 (m, 6 H).
    To a solution of (1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR, 13aR,13bR)-tert-butyldimethylsilyl 9-(4-(methoxycarbonyl)phenyl)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysene-3a-carboxylate (3.12 g, 4.54 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (25 mL) was added TBAF (75% wt. in H2O) (2.375 g, 6.81 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at rt for 4 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with 1 N HCl (25 mL) and H2O (5 mL) and extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 × 100 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and partially concentrated under reduced pressure to about 10 mL volume before adding 1 N HCl (50 mL). The solids that formed were collected by filtration and washed with H2O to give 12 (2.58 g, 4.50 mmol, 99% yield) as a white solid. LCMS: m/e 571.47 (M – H)−, 3.60 min (method 1). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ ppm 9.80 (br s, 1 H), 7.92 (d, J = 8.24 Hz, 2 H), 7.18 (d, J = 8.24 Hz, 2 H), 5.32–5.26 (m, 1 H), 4.75 (s, 1 H), 4.62 (br s, 1 H), 3.90 (s, 3 H), 3.07–2.99 (m, 1 H), 2.33–2.21 (m, 2 H), 2.10 (dd, J = 17.09, 6.10 Hz, 1 H), 2.06–1.94 (m, 2 H), 1.70 (s, 3 H), 1.01 (br s, 3 H), 1.00 (br s, 3 H), 0.98 (s, 3 H), 0.91 (s, 6 H), 1.79–0.89 (m, 17 H).

    Methyl 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-Isocyanato-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoate (13)

    To a slurry of 12 (10 g, 17.46 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (200 mL) was added Et3N (4.38 mL, 31.4 mmol), followed by diphenyl phosphoryl azide (5.82 mL, 26.2 mmol). The resulting white slurry was heated to 100 °C. After 5 h, the reaction was allowed to cool to rt, diluted with EtOAc, and washed with 1N NaOH (2 × 70 mL). The combined aqueous layer was extracted with EtOAc (2 × 150 mL). The combined organic layer was dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated to a slurry (75 mL), which was stored in a refrigerator overnight. The slurry was filtered, and the white solid product was washed with Et2O. The filtrate was concentrated to a yellow slurry, which was filtered and washed with Et2O to give additional product as a white solid. The two batches of product were combined and dried under reduced pressure to give the title compound (8.6 g, 15.09 mmol, 86% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ ppm 8.0 (2 H, d, J = 8.2 Hz), 7.2 (2 H, d, J = 8.2 Hz), 5.3 (1 H, d, J = 4.6 Hz), 4.8 (1 H, s), 4.7 (1 H, s), 3.9 (3 H, s), 2.6 (1 H, td, J = 10.8, 5.8 Hz), 2.1–2.2 (2 H, m), 1.8–2.0 (4 H, m), 1.7–1.8 (1 H, m), 1.7 (3 H, s), 1.5–1.7 (5 H, m), 1.4–1.5 (5 H, m), 1.3–1.4 (2 H, m), 1.2–1.3 (2 H, m), 1.1 (3 H, s), 1.1–1.1 (1 H, m), 1.0 (3 H, s), 1.0 (3 H, s), 1.0 (3 H, br s), 1.0 (3 H, br s). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ ppm 14.2, 15.4, 16.2, 19.2, 19.5, 20.8, 21.0, 24.7, 27.4, 29.0, 29.2, 33.3, 36.0, 37.2, 39.0, 39.0, 40.3, 41.5, 41.8, 47.8, 49.0, 49.2, 51.7, 52.6, 66.8, 71.3, 110.2, 121.3, 123.7, 127.6, 128.2, 129.8, 146.0, 148.4, 148.6, 166.9.

    Methyl 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-Amino-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoate (14)

    To a mixture of 13 (5.47 g, 9.60 mmol) in THF (100 mL) was added concentrated HCl (19.83 mL, 240 mmol). The resulting homogeneous mixture was stirred at rt for 72 h before being concentrated to dryness to give the HCl salt of the title product (4.98 g, 8.58 mmol, 89% yield) as a white solid. LCMS: m/e 544.5 (M + H)+, 3.26 min (method 2). 1H NMR (500 MHz, 1:1 CDCl3:MeOD, MeOD lock) δ ppm 7.9 (2 H, d, J = 8.5 Hz), 7.3 (1 H, t, J = 7.8 Hz), 7.2 (2 H, d, J = 8.5 Hz), 7.1 (1 H, t, J = 7.3 Hz), 5.3 (1 H, d, J = 4.6 Hz), 4.8 (1 H, s), 4.7 (1 H, br s), 3.9 (2 H, s), 3.6 (2 H, dt, J = 15.6, 6.6 Hz), 3.3 (1 H, dt, J = 3.1, 1.6 Hz), 2.6 (1 H, td, J = 11.0, 6.1 Hz), 2.1 (1 H, dd, J = 17.1, 6.4 Hz), 2.0 (1 H, d, J = 13.4 Hz), 1.9–2.0 (1 H, m), 1.8–1.9 (2 H, m), 1.7–1.7 (3 H, m), 1.6–1.7 (3 H, m), 1.5–1.6 (3 H, m), 1.5–1.5 (2 H, m), 1.4 (1 H, br s), 1.3–1.4 (1 H, m), 1.2–1.3 (1 H, m), 1.1–1.2 (2 H, m), 1.1–1.1 (1 H, m), 1.0 (3 H, s), 1.0 (3 H, s), 0.9 (3 H, s), 0.9 (3 H, s).

    General Procedure for the Preparation of C17 Amides

    Step 1: Amide Formation

    To a solution of 14 (0.2–0.5 mmol, 1 equiv) in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was added DIPEA (4–5 equiv), the corresponding carboxylic acid (1.3–1.5 equiv), and HATU (1.5–1.7 equiv). The mixture was stirred at rt overnight before being concentrated under reduced pressure. The solids formed were either crystallized from MeOH or purified by preparative HPLC to give the amide product.

    Step 2: Hydrolysis of the Benzoate Ester

    To a solution of the amide product from step 1 in THF (5 mL) was added LiOH.H2O (3–4 equiv) in H2O (1 mL). The mixture was heated at 75 °C until hydrolysis was complete (usually within 4–7 h), cooled to rt, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by preparative HPLC to give the benzoic acid product.

    General Procedure for the Alkylation of C-17 Amines and Hydrolysis of the Benzoate Ester

    To a sealable pressure vessel containing a mixture of 14 (1 equiv), alkylating agent (5 equiv), KI (1.1 equiv), and K3PO4 (5 equiv) was added CH3CN (0.02–0.1 M). The mixture was flushed with N2, then the vial was sealed and heated at 120 °C until the reaction was complete by LC/MS (typically 6–18 h). The reaction mixture was cooled to rt, diluted with H2O, and extracted with CH2Cl2. The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude alkylated product was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane, and 1N or 10N NaOH (10–50 equiv) was added. The mixture was heated at 75–80 °C for 3 h, cooled to rt, filtered, and the residue purified by preparative HPLC to give the title product. Alternatively, basic hydrolysis using LiOH could also be used as described above in the general procedure for the preparation of C17 amides.

    General Procedure for the Alkylation of the C-17 Amine via Alkylchoride 20

    A mixture of chloroethyl intermediate 20 (1 equiv), Hunig’s Base (5 equiv), and a secondary amine (2 equiv) in DMSO (3 mL) was heated to 120 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was quenched with H2O (10 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (3 × 8 mL). The extracts were combined, dried over sodium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by silica gel chromatography to provide the desired product. A mixture of carboxylate (1 equiv) and sodium hydroxide (10 equiv) in 1,4-dioxane (1 mL) was heated to 80 °C for 3 h. The reaction mixture was filtered, and the clear solution was purified by preparative HPLC. Fractions containing the product were combined and concentrated under reduced pressure to provide the desired product.

    Preparation of 20

    A mixture of 14 (1,500 mg, 2.76 mmol), 2-bromoethanol (1,034 mg, 8.27 mmol), K3PO4 (1,756 mg, 8.27 mmol), and KI (916 mg, 5.52 mmol) in CH3CN (10 mL) was heated at 120 °C for 15 h. The reaction mixture was poured into distilled H2O (40 mL) and the white precipitate filtered off, washed with distilled H2O (100 mL), and dried under reduced pressure to provide methyl 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-((2-hydroxyethyl)amino)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoate (1.4 g, 86%). LCMS: m/e 588.5 (M + H)+, 2.40 min (method 3).
    A mixture of methyl 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-((2-hydroxyethyl)amino)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoate (1.40 g, 2.381 mmol) and SOCl2 (1.74 mL, 23.8 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (15 mL) was heated at 60 °C for 2 h. The reaction mixture was concentrated under reduced pressure to provide 20 as a brown solid (1.30 g, 90%). LCMS: m/e 606.48 (M + H)+, 2.46 min (method 3).

    4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-(((2-(1,1-Dioxido-4-thiomorpholinyl)ethoxy)carbonyl)amino)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(1-methylethenyl)-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoic Acid (23)

    To a solution of 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)thiomorpholine 1,1-dioxide (377 mg, 2.11 mmol) in THF (5 mL) was added NaH (70 mg, 1.76 mmol). The resulting suspension was stirred at rt. After 25 min, 13 (200 mg, 0.35 mmol) was added in one portion. The resulting suspension was stirred for 20 h, then poured into 0.1 N HCl (5 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (2 × 50 mL). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated to give a white foam. The crude material was purified by reversed phase preparative HPLC (method 1) to give the title compound (74.4 mg, 95% HPLC purity, 0.08 mmol, 24% yield). LCMS: m/e 735.3 (M + H)+, 2.63 min (method 2). 1H NMR (500 MHz, MeOH-d4) δ = 7.95 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2 H), 7.25 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2 H), 5.33 (dd, J = 1.7, 6.3 Hz, 1 H), 4.79 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1 H), 4.66 (s, 1 H), 4.38–4.28 (m, 1 H), 4.27–4.19 (m, 1 H), 3.56–3.43 (m, 3 H), 3.31 (br s, 2 H), 3.17 (br s, 2 H), 2.71 (dt, J = 5.3, 11.1 Hz, 1 H), 2.57 (d, J = 13.4 Hz, 1 H), 2.33 (dd, J = 8.4, 12.1 Hz, 1 H), 2.18 (dd, J = 6.4, 17.1 Hz, 1 H), 2.00–1.89 (m, 2 H), 1.84–1.76 (m, 2 H), 1.75 (s, 3 H), 1.73 (d, J = 4.3 Hz, 1 H), 1.71–1.64 (m, 1 H), 1.62–1.56 (m, 2 H), 1.56–1.48 (m, 4 H), 1.47–1.35 (m, 4 H), 1.31 (dt, J = 4.0, 9.3 Hz, 2 H), 1.15 (s, 3 H), 1.12 (d, J = 3.1 Hz, 1 H), 1.07 (s, 6 H), 0.99 (s, 3 H), 0.97 (s, 3 H). 13C NMR (101 MHz MeOH-d4) δ ppm 14.5, 16.2, 16.7, 19.2, 20.6, 21.3, 22.1, 26.2, 28.2, 29.7, 30.4, 34.5, 35.8, 37.1, 38.1, 38.2, 41.5, 42.5, 42.8, 46.5, 47.8, 49.3, 50.1, 50.5, 50.7, 52.1, 54.0, 56.3, 60.9, 65.0, 110.3, 124.9, 129.4, 130.9, 147.4, 149.7, 150.8, 156.2, 169.6.

    Preparation of 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-(((2-(1,1-Dioxido-4-thiomorpholinyl)ethyl)carbamoyl)amino)-1-isopropenyl-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoic Acid (24)

    To a vial containing 13 (0.15 g, 0.26 mmol) was added 4-(2-aminoethyl)thiomorpholine 1,1-dioxide (0.14 g, 0.79 mmol), followed by THF (2 mL) and DIPEA (0.14 mL, 0.79 mmol). The vial was capped, and the mixture was shaken at rt for 2 h. The mixture was concentrated to half of its original volume and then diluted with MeOH and THF, filtered, and purified by preparative HPLC (method 1). The fractions containing the product were combined and concentrated to give the urea product (0.170 g, 0.196 mmol, 74% yield) as a white solid. To a vial containing the urea (120 mg, 0.14 mmol) was added LiOH·H2O (0.04 g, 0.84 mmol), H2O (1 mL), and 1,4-dioxane (2 mL). The mixture was heated at 75 °C for 1 h before being concentrated under a stream of N2. The crude material was dissolved in THF and MeOH, filtered, and purified by preparative HPLC (method 2) to give the title product (121 mg, 98% HPLC purity, 0.14 mmol, 100% yield) as a white solid. LCMS: m/z 734 (M + H+), retention time 2.49 min (method 3). 1H NMR (500 MHz, 1:1 mixture of CDCl3 and MeOD, MeOD lock) δ ppm, 7.93 (m, J = 8.24 Hz, 2 H) 7.21 (m, J = 8.24 Hz, 2 H), 5.29 (d, J = 4.58 Hz, 1 H), 4.75 (d, J = 1.22 Hz, 1 H), 4.63 (s, 1 H), 3.69 (br s, 4 H), 3.39–3.52 (m, 6 H), 3.20 (br s, 2 H), 2.52–2.63 (m, 2 H), 2.35 (dd, J = 12.05, 8.39 Hz, 1 H), 2.13 (dd, J = 17.24, 6.26 Hz, 1 H), 1.86–2.00 (m, 1 H), 1.63–1.82 (m, 8 H), 1.21–1.60 (m, 11 H), 1.11–1.17 (m, 2 H), 1.10 (s, 3 H), 1.03 (br s, 3 H), 1.02 (br s, 3 H), 0.95 (s, 3 H), 0.94 (s, 3 H).

    4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-((3-(1,1-Dioxido-4-thiomorpholinyl)-1-oxopropyl)amino)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(1-methylethenyl)-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoic Acid (25)

    The title compound was prepared following the general procedure for the preparation of C-17 amides using 3-(1,1-dioxidothiomorpholino)propanoic acid in step 1. The crude material was purified by reversed phase preparative HPLC (method 3) to give the title compound as a white solid (115 mg, 96% HPLC purity, 0.13 mmol, 70% yield over 2 steps). m/e 719.5 (M + H)+, 1.88 min (method 2). 1H NMR (500 MHz, 2:1 MeOH-d4:CDCl3) δ = 7.93 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 2 H), 7.25 (br s, 1 H), 7.21 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 2 H), 5.30 (d, J = 6.1 Hz, 1 H), 4.78 (s, 1 H), 4.66 (s, 1 H), 3.47 (br s, 4 H), 3.36 (br s, 4 H), 3.19 (br s, 2 H), 2.72–2.59 (m, 4 H), 2.40 (dd, J = 8.9, 11.9 Hz, 1 H), 2.15 (dd, J = 6.3, 17.2 Hz, 1 H), 1.98–1.86 (m, 2 H), 1.80 (d, J = 13.1 Hz, 1 H), 1.73 (s, 3 H), 1.71–1.66 (m, 1 H), 1.63–1.43 (m, 8 H), 1.42–1.23 (m, 5 H), 1.22–1.13 (m, 2 H), 1.12 (s, 3 H), 1.05 (br s, 3 H), 1.04 (br s, 3 H), 0.97 (br s, 3 H), 0.95 (br s, 3 H). 13C NMR (101 MHz 2:1 MeOH-d4:CDCl3) δ ppm 15.0, 16.5, 17.1, 19.6, 20.7, 21.6, 22.3, 26.3, 28.3, 29.5, 30.0, 30.5, 33.1, 34.5, 35.6, 37.2, 38.4, 38.5, 41.6, 42.6, 42.9, 48.1, 50.2, 50.4, 50.5, 51.8, 53.8, 53.9, 66.3, 110.9, 124.9, 129.3, 129.6, 131.0, 147.4, 149.7, 150.4, 169.9, 172.2.

    4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-(((1,1-Dioxido-4-thiomorpholinyl)acetyl)amino)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(1-methylethenyl)-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl) benzoic Acid (26)

    The title compound was prepared following the general procedure for the preparation of C-17 amides using 2-(1,1-dioxidothiomorpholino)acetic acid in step 1. The crude material was purified by reversed phase preparative HPLC (method 3) to give the title compound as a white solid (90.3 mg, 100% HPLC purity, 0.11 mmol, 61% yield over 2 steps). LCMS: m/e 704.5 (M + H)+, 1.90 min (method 2). 1H NMR (500 MHz, 2:1 MeOD:CDCl3) δ = 7.93 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2 H), 7.23 (br s, 1 H), 7.21 (s, 2 H), 5.31 (dd, J = 1.7, 6.0 Hz, 1 H), 4.78 (d, J = 1.2 Hz, 1 H), 4.67 (s, 1 H), 3.29 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 4 H), 3.24 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 4 H), 2.67–2.60 (m, 1 H), 2.53 (dt, J = 5.5, 10.8 Hz, 1 H), 2.47 (dd, J = 8.1, 12.7 Hz, 1 H), 2.16 (dd, J = 6.3, 17.2 Hz, 1 H), 1.94–1.78 (m, 3 H), 1.76 (d, J = 2.1 Hz, 1 H), 1.74 (s, 3 H), 1.62–1.49 (m, 7 H), 1.47–1.33 (m, 4 H), 1.31–1.25 (m, 1 H), 1.21–1.13 (m, 2 H), 1.12 (s, 3 H), 1.07 (s, 3 H), 1.05 (s, 3 H), 0.97 (s, 3 H), 0.96 (s, 3 H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, 2:1 MeOH-d4:CDCl3) δ ppm 15.0, 16.3, 17.1, 19.5, 20.7, 21.6, 22.2, 26.2, 28.2, 29.5, 30.0, 30.5, 34.4, 35.3, 37.2, 38.3, 39.3, 41.5, 42.6, 42.9, 49.7, 50.1, 50.4, 51.1, 52.4, 53.9, 60.2, 65.9, 79.0, 111.1, 124.9, 129.4, 129.6, 131.0, 147.4, 149.7, 150.1, 169.8, 169.9.

    4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-((2-(1,1-Dioxido-4-thiomorpholinyl)-1-oxopropyl)amino)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(1-methylethenyl)-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl) benzoic Acid (27)

    The title compound was prepared following the general procedure for the preparation of C-17 amides using 2-(1,1-dioxidothiomorpholin-4-yl)-propionic acid in step 1. The crude material was purified by reverse phase preparative HPLC (method 3) to give the title compound as a white solid (127 mg, 96% HPLC purity, 0.15 mmol, 44% yield over 2 steps). LCMS: m/e 719.5 (M + H)+, 2.03 min (method 2). 1H NMR (500 MHz, 1:1 CDCl3:MeOH-d4) δ = 7.92 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2 H), 7.54 (s, 1 H), 7.20 (d, J = 7.9 Hz, 2 H), 5.29 (d, J = 5.2 Hz, 1 H), 4.75 (d, J = 10.4 Hz, 1 H), 4.66 (br s, 1 H), 3.48–3.39 (m, 1 H), 3.28–3.11 (m, 8 H), 2.69–2.55 (m, 1 H), 2.50–2.34 (m, 2 H), 2.13 (dd, J = 6.1, 17.1 Hz, 1 H), 1.80 (d, J = 11.6 Hz, 2 H), 1.72 (s, 6 H), 1.59–1.44 (m, 8 H), 1.43–1.36 (m, 2 H), 1.33 (dd, J = 6.9, 14.8 Hz, 4 H), 1.25 (d, J = 6.7 Hz, 1 H), 1.15 (d, J = 11.0 Hz, 2 H), 1.08 (s, 3 H), 1.03 (s, 3 H), 1.01 (s, 3 H), 0.94 (br s, 6 H).

    4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-(2-(1,1-Dioxidothiomorpholino)-3-methylbutanamido)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoic Acid (28)

    The title compound was prepared following the general procedure for the preparation of C-17 amides using 2-(1,1-dioxidothiomorpholino)-3-methylbutanoic acid in step 1. The crude material was purified by reversed phase preparative HPLC (method 3) to give the title compound. LCMS: m/e 747.5 (M + H)+, 2.29 min (method 2). 1H NMR (500 MHz, 1:1 CDCl3:MeOH-d4) δ = 7.92 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2 H), 7.20 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2 H), 6.40 (s, 1 H), 5.29 (dd, J = 1.5, 6.1 Hz, 1 H), 4.76 (d, J = 1.5 Hz, 1 H), 4.64 (s, 1 H), 3.77–3.72 (m, 1 H), 3.23–3.14 (m, 2 H), 3.13–3.06 (m, 4 H), 3.05–2.99 (m, 2 H), 2.80 (d, J = 10.4 Hz, 1 H), 2.74–2.67 (m, 1 H), 2.61 (dt, J = 5.3, 11.1 Hz, 1 H), 2.49 (dd, J = 8.4, 12.7 Hz, 1 H), 2.12 (dd, J = 6.4, 17.1 Hz, 1 H), 2.08–2.01 (m, 1 H), 1.99–1.91 (m, 1 H), 1.88 (ddd, J = 3.1, 3.3, 6.8 Hz, 1 H), 1.86–1.82 (m, 1 H), 1.78 (d, J = 11.0 Hz, 1 H), 1.72 (br s, 1 H), 1.71 (s, 3 H), 1.69 (d, J = 4.6 Hz, 1 H), 1.67–1.63 (m, 1 H), 1.61–1.53 (m, 2 H), 1.51 (br s, 1 H), 1.48 (br s, 2 H), 1.47–1.41 (m, 2 H), 1.12 (dd, J = 3.4, 13.4 Hz, 2 H), 1.07 (s, 3 H), 1.01 (br s, 3 H), 1.00 (s, 3 H), 0.99 (s, 3 H), 0.97 (d, J = 6.7 Hz, 3 H), 0.93 (s, 3 H), 0.93 (s, 3 H). 13C NMR (101 MHz 1:1 CDCl3:MeOH-d4) δ ppm 172.2, 170.1, 150.3, 149.8, 147.4, 131.0, 129.7, 129.2, 124.9, 111.3, 78.7, 76.0, 68.9, 66.7, 53.9, 53.6, 50.5, 50.2, 50.0, 49.8, 49.6, 48.2, 43.0, 42.8, 41.7, 38.4, 37.3, 35.9, 34.6, 30.6, 30.2, 29.5, 28.4, 28.1, 26.5, 26.2, 22.3, 21.8, 20.7, 20.1, 19.7, 17.4, 16.7, 15.2.

    4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-((3-(1,1-Dioxidothiomorpholino)propyl)amino)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoic Acid (29)

    To a solution of 14 (40 mg, 0.07 mmol) in EtOH (1.0 mL) and 1,4-dioxane (1.0 mL) was added AcOH (0.01 mL, 0.22 mmol) and tert-butyl 3-oxopropylcarbamate (38.2 mg, 0.22 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred for 2 h, NaBH(OAc)3 (78 mg, 0.37 mmol) was added, and stirring continued at rt for 2 h. The mixture was quenched with satd aq NaHCO3, diluted with 0.1 N HCl, and extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 × 5 mL). The organic layers were washed with brine, dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure to provide 18 as a pale-yellow oil (28 mg, 0.04 mmol, 54% yield). LCMS: m/e 701.5 (M + H)+, 3.92 min (method 2).
    To a solution of 18 (23 mg, 0.03 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane was added HCl (4 M in 1,4-dioxane) (33 μL, 0.13 mmol), the reaction mixture was stirred for 6 h at rt before being concentrated under reduced pressure to provide methyl 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-(3-aminopropylamino)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoate as a brown oil (15 mg, 0.03 mmol, 76% yield). LCMS: m/e 601.5 (M + H)+, 2.88 min (method 2).
    To a mixture of methyl 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-(3-aminopropylamino)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoate (15 mg, 0.03 mmol) in EtOH (1 mL) was added vinylsulfonylethene (5.9 mg, 0.05 mmol) and TEA (7.0 μL, 0.05 mmol). The reaction mixture was heated at 100 °C for 3 h before being concentrated under reduced pressure to provide methyl 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-((3-(1,1-dioxidothiomorpholino)propyl)amino)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoate as a brown solid (15 mg, 0.02 mmol, 84% yield). LCMS: m/e 719.46 (M + H)+, 3.62 min (method 2).
    To a mixture of methyl 4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-3a-((3-(1,1-dioxidothiomorpholino)propyl)amino)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-pentamethyl-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoate (15 mg, 0.02 mmol) in 1,4-dioxane (1 mL) was added 1 N NaOH (0.10 mL, 0.10 mmol), and the mixture was heated at 78 °C for 3 h. The mixture was cooled to rt and the product purified by preparative HPLC with a MeOH/H2O/TFA gradient to provide 29 as a white solid (9 mg, 95% HPLC purity, 0.01 mmol, 58% yield). LCMS: m/e 705.49 (M + H)+, 2.60 min (method 2). 1H NMR (400 MHz, AcOH-d4) δ ppm 7.99 (d, J = 8.28 Hz, 2 H), 7.25 (d, J = 8.28 Hz, 2 H), 5.33 (d, J = 4.77 Hz, 1 H), 4.82 (s, 1 H), 4.71 (s, 1 H), 3.87 (br s, 4 H), 3.56 (d, J = 4.27 Hz, 4 H), 3.51–3.40 (m, 2 H), 3.39–3.22 (m, 2 H), 2.86–2.69 (m, 1 H), 2.57–2.34 (m, 2 H), 2.27–1.18 (m, 22 H), 1.72 (s, 3 H), 1.16 (s, 3 H), 1.10 (s, 3 H), 1.04 (s, 3 H), 0.98 (s, 3 H), 0.96 (s, 3 H).

    4-((1R,3aS,5aR,5bR,7aR,11aS,11bR,13aR,13bR)-5a,5b,8,8,11a-Pentamethyl-3a-(2-morpholinoethylamino)-1-(prop-1-en-2-yl)-2,3,3a,4,5,5a,5b,6,7,7a,8,11,11a,11b,12,13,13a,13b-octadecahydro-1H-cyclopenta[a]chrysen-9-yl)benzoic Acid (30)

    The title compound was prepared following the representative procedure for the alkylation of C-17 amines and hydrolysis of the benzoate ester above using 4-(2-chloroethyl)morpholine hydrochloride as the alkylating agent. The product was isolated as a white solid (65 mg, 90% HPLC purity, 49% yield over 2 steps). LCMS: m/e 643.6 (M + H)+, 2.35 min (method 4). 1H NMR (400 MHz, MeOH-d4) δ ppm 7.95 (m, J = 8.3 Hz, 2 H), 7.24 (m, J = 8.3 Hz, 2 H), 5.31 (d, J = 4.8 Hz, 1 H), 4.86 (s, 1 H), 4.74 (s, 1 H), 3.82–3.99 (m, 4 H), 3.37–3.58 (m, 4 H), 3.21 (d, J = 4.5 Hz, 2 H), 3.19 (br s, 2 H), 2.67–2.86 (m, 1 H), 2.02–2.26 (m, 5 H), 1.83–1.90 (m, 1 H), 1.64–1.81 (m, 8 H), 1.45–1.64 (m, 7 H), 1.34–1.45 (m, 2 H), 1.27–1.34 (m, 1 H), 1.15–1.27 (m, 4 H), 1.12 (s, 3 H), 1.04 (s, 3 H), 0.99 (s, 3 H), 0.93 (s, 3 H).
